docs.title: Database Management - BADM 554
docs.text: Welcome to the Database Management textbook for BADM 554 at the University of Illinois.

docs.title: Course Overview
docs.text: Databases play a critical role in today's business environment. Almost all modern organizations use database technologies to store and manage data in every functional area including operations, finance, accounting, and marketing. This course will equip you with one of the most marketable skills to help businesses better manage their data and discover new opportunities.

docs.title: What You Will Learn
docs.text:
By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  1. Understand and articulate the data needs of a company (requirement analysis)
  2. Conceptually model the relationship of data (data modeling)
  3. Query databases using SQL to meet business requirements (structured and non-relational)
  4. Extract, Transform, and Load (ETL) data from/to multiple sources
  5. Understand infrastructure needs to handle Big Data and build BI and ML workflows

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
After completing this chapter, you will be able to:

  • Understand what a database is and why it's important for business
  • Explain the difference between data and information
  • Describe the components of a database system
  • Understand the role of a Database Management System (DBMS)
  • Identify the advantages and disadvantages of database systems
  • Recognize different types of database users

docs.title: What is Data?
docs.text:
Data consists of raw facts about entities (things) and events. Examples include:

  • Customer names, addresses, and phone numbers
  • Product prices and quantities
  • Transaction dates and amounts
  • Employee IDs and salaries

Data alone is not particularly useful until it is processed and organized.

docs.title: What is Information?
docs.text:
Information is data that has been processed to increase knowledge and reduce uncertainty. For example:

  • Data: Customer purchase records over the past year
  • Information: "Our top 10 customers account for 45% of revenue"

docs.title: What is a Database?
docs.text:
A database is a shared, integrated computer structure that stores:

  • End-user data: The actual data (facts) about entities and events
  • Metadata: Data about data - descriptions of data characteristics and relationships

Real-World Database Example

A university database might contain:

End-user data: - Student records (ID, name, major, GPA) - Course information (course code, title, credits) - Enrollment data (which students are in which courses)

Metadata: - Student ID is a 9-digit number - GPA is a decimal number between 0.0 and 4.0 - Course code is a combination of 4 letters and 3 numbers

docs.title: 1.2 Why Databases Matter in Business
docs.text: Databases are critical in modern business for several reasons:

docs.title: 1. Data is a Strategic Asset
docs.text: Organizations use data to: - Make informed decisions - Understand customer behavior - Optimize operations - Gain competitive advantage

docs.title: 2. Data Supports Every Business Function
docs.text: Business Function Database Use Case Marketing Customer segmentation, campaign tracking, customer lifetime value analysis Finance Financial reporting, budgeting, risk analysis Operations Inventory management, supply chain optimization, quality control Human Resources Employee records, payroll, performance tracking Accounting Transaction processing, audit trails, fraud detection

docs.title: 3. Data Enables Innovation
docs.text:
Modern businesses use databases to: - Develop new products based on customer insights - Personalize customer experiences - Automate business processes - Enable machine learning and AI applications

Career Relevance

Database skills are among the most in-demand skills across all business roles. Even if you're not an "IT person," understanding databases will make you significantly more valuable as an employee.

docs.title: 1.3 Database Management Systems (DBMS)
docs.text: A Database Management System (DBMS) is a collection of programs that manages the database structure and controls access to the data.

docs.title: Key Components of a DBMS
docs.text:
1. Hardware: The physical devices (servers, storage)
  2. Software: The DBMS software (MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, etc.)
  3. Data: The actual information stored in the database
  4. Procedures: Instructions and rules for using the database
  5. People: Database users and administrators

docs.title: DBMS Functions
docs.text: A DBMS provides several critical functions:

docs.title: Data Dictionary Management
docs.text:
• Stores definitions of data elements and relationships
  • Ensures data consistency across applications

docs.title: Data Storage Management
docs.text:
• Manages where and how data is physically stored
  • Optimizes storage for performance and efficiency

docs.title: Data Transformation
docs.text:
• Transforms entered data into required data structures
  • Handles data type conversions

docs.title: Security Management
docs.text:
• Enforces user security and data privacy rules
  • Controls who can access what data

docs.title: Multi-user Access Control
docs.text:
• Allows multiple users to access data simultaneously
  • Prevents conflicts when multiple users modify the same data

docs.title: Backup and Recovery
docs.text:
• Ensures data can be recovered after failures
  • Maintains data integrity during system crashes

docs.title: Data Integrity Management
docs.text:
• Enforces business rules and constraints
  • Ensures data accuracy and consistency

docs.title: Database Query Language
docs.text:
• Provides a language (like SQL) to interact with data
  • Allows users to retrieve and manipulate data

docs.title: 1. Improved Data Sharing
docs.text:
• Multiple users and applications can access the same data
  • Data is available to all authorized users across the organization

docs.title: 2. Improved Data Security
docs.text:
• Centralized control over who can access what data
  • Encryption and access controls protect sensitive information

docs.title: 3. Better Data Integration
docs.text:
• Related data from different sources can be combined
  • Provides a unified view of enterprise data

docs.title: 4. Minimized Data Inconsistency
docs.text:
• Data redundancy is reduced
  • Updates are made in one place, ensuring consistency

docs.title: 5. Improved Data Access
docs.text:
• Query languages (like SQL) make it easy to retrieve data
  • Ad-hoc queries allow flexible data analysis

docs.title: 6. Improved Decision Making
docs.text:
• Better-managed data and improved access leads to better decisions
  • Data quality improvements result in more reliable insights

docs.title: 7. Increased Productivity
docs.text:
• Standard procedures and reduced redundancy save time
  • Automated processes reduce manual work

Business Scenario: Marketing Department

Before Database: - Customer lists in multiple Excel files - Duplicates across different spreadsheets - No easy way to track customer interactions - Difficult to segment customers for targeted campaigns

After Database: - Single source of truth for customer data - No duplicates - each customer has one record - Complete history of interactions - Easy segmentation and targeted marketing - Measurable campaign ROI

docs.title: 1.5 Disadvantages and Challenges
docs.text: While databases provide many benefits, they also come with challenges:

docs.title: 1. Increased Costs
docs.text:
• Software costs: DBMS licenses can be expensive
  • Hardware costs: Servers and storage infrastructure
  • Training costs: Staff need to learn new skills
  • Maintenance costs: Ongoing support and updates

docs.title: 2. Complexity
docs.text:
• Database systems can be complex to design and manage
  • Requires specialized knowledge and skills

docs.title: 3. Security Risks
docs.text:
• Centralized data creates a single point of attack
  • Data breaches can be catastrophic
  • Requires robust security measures

docs.title: 4. Performance Issues
docs.text:
• Poorly designed databases can be slow
  • Requires careful tuning and optimization

docs.title: 1.6 Types of Database Users
docs.text: Different people interact with databases in different ways:

docs.title: 1. End Users
docs.text:
• Use database applications to interact with data
  • Examples: Sales reps entering orders, HR staff updating employee records
  • Don't need to know SQL or database internals

docs.title: 2. Application Developers
docs.text:
• Create applications that use databases
  • Write SQL queries and database code
  • Need to understand database design and optimization

docs.title: 3. Database Administrators (DBAs)
docs.text:
• Manage the database system
  • Ensure security, performance, and availability
  • Handle backups, recovery, and user access

docs.title: 4. Database Designers
docs.text:
• Design the structure of the database
  • Create data models and schemas
  • Ensure data integrity and efficiency

docs.title: 5. System Administrators
docs.text:
• Manage the hardware and operating systems
  • Work with DBAs to ensure system reliability

docs.title: 1.7 Evolution of Database Systems
docs.text: Understanding how databases evolved helps explain why they work the way they do:

docs.title: File Systems (1960s)
docs.text:
• Data stored in separate files for each application
  • High data redundancy
  • Difficult to share data between applications

docs.title: Hierarchical and Network Databases (1970s)
docs.text:
• Organized data in tree or graph structures
  • Complex to navigate and query
  • Limited flexibility

docs.title: Relational Databases (1980s-Present)
docs.text:
• Data organized in tables (relations)
  • Uses SQL for querying
  • Currently the most popular type
  • Examples: MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, SQL Server

docs.title: NoSQL Databases (2000s-Present)
docs.text:
• Designed for big data and high scalability
  • Flexible schemas
  • Examples: MongoDB, Cassandra, Redis

docs.title: NewSQL and Cloud Databases (2010s-Present)
docs.text:
• Combines benefits of relational and NoSQL
  • Cloud-based services (AWS RDS, Google Cloud SQL)
  • Serverless options

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
1. Databases store organized data that can be processed into useful information
  2. DBMS software manages databases and provides essential functions like security, backup, and multi-user access
  3. Databases benefit businesses by improving data sharing, security, integration, and decision-making
  4. Database skills are valuable across all business functions, not just IT
  5. Different database types exist for different needs (relational, NoSQL, etc.)

docs.title: 2.1 The Relational Model
docs.text: The relational model, developed by E.F. Codd in 1970, represents data as a collection of relations (tables). This model is the foundation of modern database systems like MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, and SQL Server.

docs.title: Why "Relational"?
docs.text: The term "relational" comes from the mathematical concept of relations, not from relationships between tables (though those exist too!). Each table represents a relation, which is a set of tuples (rows).

docs.title: 2.2 Tables (Relations)
docs.text: A table (or relation) is a two-dimensional structure consisting of rows and columns.

docs.title: Terminology
docs.text: Formal Term Common Term Definition Relation Table A two-dimensional structure of data Tuple Row/Record A single entry in a table Attribute Column/Field A characteristic or property Domain Data Type Set of allowable values for an attribute Cardinality Row count Number of tuples in a relation Degree Column count Number of attributes in a relation

docs.title: Table Characteristics
docs.text:
A proper relational table must have these characteristics:

  1. Each column has a unique name

  2. Column names cannot be repeated in the same table

  3. All values in a column are from the same domain

  4. All values in the GPA column must be numbers between 0.0 and 4.0

  5. Each row is unique

  6. No two rows can be exactly identical

  7. The order of rows is irrelevant

  8. Tables are sets, not lists

  9. The order of columns is irrelevant

  10. Columns can be rearranged without changing the table's meaning

  11. Each cell contains a single value (atomic)

  12. No lists or multiple values in a single cell

Table Characteristics in Practice

Good Table (Follows Rules): 

PRODUCT
+------------+------------------+--------+
| Product_ID | Product_Name     | Price  |
+------------+------------------+--------+
| P001       | Laptop           | 999.99 |
| P002       | Mouse            | 24.99  |
+------------+------------------+--------+

Bad Table (Violates Atomic Value Rule): 

ORDER
+----------+------------------------+
| Order_ID | Products               |
+----------+------------------------+
| O001     | Laptop, Mouse, Keyboard|  ← Multiple values!
+----------+------------------------+

docs.title: 2.3 Keys
docs.text: Keys are attributes (or combinations of attributes) that uniquely identify rows in a table.

docs.title: 1. Super Key
docs.text:
A super key is any attribute (or set of attributes) that uniquely identifies a tuple.

Example: In the STUDENT table: - Student_ID is a super key - {Student_ID, Name} is also a super key - {Student_ID, Name, Major} is also a super key

docs.title: 2. Candidate Key
docs.text:
A candidate key is a minimal super key - no subset of it can uniquely identify tuples.

Example: - Student_ID is a candidate key (minimal) - {Student_ID, Name} is NOT a candidate key (not minimal - we can remove Name)

docs.title: 3. Primary Key (PK)
docs.text:
A primary key is the candidate key chosen to be the main identifier for the table.

Rules for primary keys: - Must be unique - Cannot be NULL - Should be stable (not change over time) - Preferably simple (single column if possible)

Example: 

STUDENT
+------------+------------------+--------+------+
| Student_ID | Name             | Major  | GPA  |  ← Student_ID is the PK
+------------+------------------+--------+------+

docs.title: 4. Foreign Key (FK)
docs.text:
A foreign key is an attribute in one table that references the primary key of another table.

Example: 

ENROLLMENT
+---------------+------------+-------------+-------+
| Enrollment_ID | Student_ID | Course_Code | Grade |  ← Student_ID is an FK
+---------------+------------+-------------+-------+

STUDENT
+------------+------------------+--------+------+
| Student_ID | Name             | Major  | GPA  |  ← Student_ID is the PK
+------------+------------------+--------+------+

The Student_ID in ENROLLMENT references the Student_ID in STUDENT.

docs.title: 5. Composite Key
docs.text:
A composite key is a primary key made up of two or more attributes.

Example: 

ENROLLMENT
+------------+-------------+-------+
| Student_ID | Course_Code | Grade |  ← {Student_ID, Course_Code} is a composite PK
+------------+-------------+-------+

A student can enroll in multiple courses, and a course can have multiple students, but each combination of student + course is unique.

docs.title: Choosing Good Keys
docs.text:
Best Practices for Primary Keys

Good PK choices: - Student_ID (created for this purpose) - Product_SKU (unique identifier) - Order_Number (system-generated)

Poor PK choices: - Name (not unique, can change) - Email (can change) - Phone_Number (can change, may not be unique internationally)

docs.title: 2.4 Integrity Rules
docs.text: Integrity rules ensure data accuracy and consistency.

docs.title: 1. Entity Integrity
docs.text:
Rule: The primary key cannot be NULL.

Why? If the primary key is NULL, we cannot uniquely identify that row.

Example: 

STUDENT
+------------+------------------+--------+------+
| Student_ID | Name             | Major  | GPA  |
+------------+------------------+--------+------+
| NULL       | Alice Johnson    | MIS    | 3.8  |  ← INVALID!
| 987654321  | Bob Smith        | FIN    | 3.5  |  ← Valid
+------------+------------------+--------+------+

docs.title: 2. Referential Integrity
docs.text:
Rule: A foreign key must either: - Match a primary key value in the referenced table, OR - Be NULL (if allowed)

Why? We shouldn't have references to non-existent records.

Example: 

ENROLLMENT                           STUDENT
+---------------+------------+       +------------+------+
| Enrollment_ID | Student_ID |       | Student_ID | Name |
+---------------+------------+       +------------+------+
| E001          | 123456789  | ✓ OK  | 123456789  | Alice|
| E002          | 999999999  | ✗ BAD | 987654321  | Bob  |
+---------------+------------+       +------------+------+
                     ↑
      Student 999999999 doesn't exist!

docs.title: 3. Domain Integrity
docs.text:
Rule: All values in a column must be from the appropriate domain.

Examples: - GPA must be between 0.0 and 4.0 - Email must contain an @ symbol - Date_of_Birth must be a valid date

docs.title: 4. Key Integrity
docs.text:
Rule: Each primary key value must be unique within the table.

Example: 

STUDENT
+------------+------------------+
| Student_ID | Name             |
+------------+------------------+
| 123456789  | Alice Johnson    |  ✓ OK
| 123456789  | Bob Smith        |  ✗ INVALID! Duplicate key
+------------+------------------+

docs.title: 2.5 Relational Algebra
docs.text: Relational algebra is a formal language for querying relational databases. It provides the theoretical foundation for SQL.

docs.title: 1. SELECT (σ) - Filter Rows
docs.text:
The SELECT operator filters rows based on a condition.

Notation: σcondition(Table)

Example: 

σ_{GPA > 3.5}(STUDENT)

Returns students with GPA greater than 3.5

docs.title: 2. PROJECT (π) - Choose Columns
docs.text:
The PROJECT operator selects specific columns.

Notation: πcolumn1, column2, ...(Table)

Example: 

π_{Student_ID, Name}(STUDENT)

Returns only the Student_ID and Name columns

docs.title: 3. UNION (∪) - Combine Rows
docs.text:
The UNION operator combines rows from two tables (tables must have the same structure).

Notation: Table1 ∪ Table2

Example: 

SPRING_STUDENTS ∪ FALL_STUDENTS

Returns all students from both semesters (no duplicates)

docs.title: 4. INTERSECTION (∩) - Common Rows
docs.text:
The INTERSECTION operator returns rows that appear in both tables.

Notation: Table1 ∩ Table2

Example: 

SPRING_STUDENTS ∩ FALL_STUDENTS

Returns students who enrolled in both semesters

docs.title: 5. DIFFERENCE (−) - Remove Rows
docs.text:
The DIFFERENCE operator returns rows in the first table but not in the second.

Notation: Table1 − Table2

Example: 

SPRING_STUDENTS − GRADUATED_STUDENTS

Returns students who were enrolled in spring but haven't graduated

docs.title: 6. CARTESIAN PRODUCT (×) - All Combinations
docs.text:
The CARTESIAN PRODUCT creates all possible combinations of rows from two tables.

Notation: Table1 × Table2

Example: If Table1 has 3 rows and Table2 has 4 rows, the result has 3 × 4 = 12 rows.

docs.title: 7. JOIN (⋈) - Combine Related Rows
docs.text:
The JOIN operator combines rows from two tables based on a related column.

Notation: Table1 ⋈condition Table2

Example: 

STUDENT ⋈_{STUDENT.Student_ID = ENROLLMENT.Student_ID} ENROLLMENT

Returns students with their enrollments

docs.title: Combining Operators
docs.text:
Relational algebra operators can be combined to create complex queries:

Example: Find names of students with GPA > 3.5 

π_{Name}(σ_{GPA > 3.5}(STUDENT))

Step-by-step: 1. σGPA > 3.5(STUDENT) - Filter students with GPA > 3.5 2. πName(...) - Project only the Name column

docs.title: 2.6 Practical Example: University Database
docs.text: Let's see how these concepts work together:

docs.title: Sample Queries Using Relational Algebra
docs.text:
Q1: Find all MIS majors 

σ_{Major = 'MIS'}(STUDENT)

Q2: Find student IDs and course codes for all enrollments 

π_{Student_ID, Course_Code}(ENROLLMENT)

Q3: Find names of students enrolled in BADM350 

π_{Name}(
  STUDENT ⋈_{STUDENT.Student_ID = ENROLLMENT.Student_ID}
  (σ_{Course_Code = 'BADM350'}(ENROLLMENT))
)

docs.title: Marketing: Customer Segmentation
docs.text:
HIGH_VALUE_CUSTOMERS = σ_{Total_Purchases > 1000}(CUSTOMER)

RECENT_BUYERS = σ_{Last_Purchase_Date > '2024-01-01'}(CUSTOMER)

TARGET_LIST = HIGH_VALUE_CUSTOMERS ∩ RECENT_BUYERS

docs.title: Finance: Overdue Invoices
docs.text:
OVERDUE = σ_{Due_Date < TODAY AND Status ≠ 'PAID'}(INVOICE)

π_{Customer_Name, Invoice_Number, Amount}(
  CUSTOMER ⋈ OVERDUE
)

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
1. Tables are the foundation of relational databases - they organize data in rows and columns
  2. Keys uniquely identify rows - Primary keys identify rows within a table, foreign keys link tables
  3. Integrity rules ensure data quality - Entity, referential, domain, and key integrity
  4. Relational algebra provides operations - SELECT, PROJECT, JOIN, UNION, and others
  5. These concepts underlie SQL - Understanding relational algebra helps you write better SQL

docs.title: What is SQL?
docs.text: SQL (Structured Query Language) is the standard language for interacting with relational databases. It's used by all major database systems including MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, SQL Server, and SQLite.

docs.title: Why SQL Matters
docs.text:
SQL is one of the most valuable skills for business professionals because:

  • Universal: Works across all relational databases with minor variations
  • Powerful: Can retrieve and manipulate complex data with simple commands
  • In-demand: One of the top skills employers look for
  • Accessible: Easier to learn than most programming languages

docs.title: SQL Categories
docs.text:
SQL commands fall into several categories:

Category Purpose Examples DDL (Data Definition Language) Define database structure CREATE, ALTER, DROP DML (Data Manipulation Language) Manipulate data SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE DCL (Data Control Language) Control access GRANT, REVOKE TCL (Transaction Control Language) Manage transactions COMMIT, ROLLBACK

In this course, we'll focus primarily on DDL and DML.

docs.title: 3.3 Data Types
docs.text: Choosing the right data type is crucial for data integrity and performance.

docs.title: Numeric Data Types
docs.text:
Data Type Description Example Use INT Whole numbers Employee ID, Age, Quantity DECIMAL(p,s) Fixed-point decimal Salary (10,2), Price (8,2) FLOAT / DOUBLE Floating-point decimal Scientific calculations TINYINT Small integers (0-255) Age, Rating (1-5) BIGINT Large integers Large transaction IDs

Examples: 

employee_id INT              -- -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647
salary DECIMAL(10,2)         -- Up to 99,999,999.99
age TINYINT                  -- 0 to 255
product_views BIGINT         -- Very large numbers

docs.title: String Data Types
docs.text:
Data Type Description Example Use CHAR(n) Fixed-length string State codes (CHAR(2)) VARCHAR(n) Variable-length string Names, emails, descriptions TEXT Large text Articles, reviews, comments ENUM Predefined values Status ('active', 'inactive')

Examples: 

state_code CHAR(2)           -- Always exactly 2 characters: 'IL', 'CA'
email VARCHAR(100)           -- Up to 100 characters
description TEXT             -- Large amounts of text
status ENUM('active', 'inactive', 'pending')

CHAR vs VARCHAR

  • Use CHAR when length is always the same (state codes, country codes)
  • Use VARCHAR when length varies (names, emails, addresses)
  • VARCHAR saves space but CHAR can be slightly faster

docs.title: Date and Time Data Types
docs.text:
Data Type Format Example DATE YYYY-MM-DD 2025-11-22 TIME HH:MM:SS 14:30:00 DATETIME YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS 2025-11-22 14:30:00 TIMESTAMP YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS 2025-11-22 14:30:00 YEAR YYYY 2025

Examples: 

birth_date DATE              -- 1990-05-15
hire_datetime DATETIME       -- 2023-01-15 09:00:00
last_updated TIMESTAMP       -- Automatically updated

docs.title: Boolean Data Type
docs.text:
is_active BOOLEAN           -- TRUE or FALSE (stored as 1 or 0)
-- Often implemented as TINYINT(1) in MySQL

docs.title: Choosing Data Types: Examples
docs.text:
CREATE TABLE customer (
    customer_id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    first_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    last_name VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    email VARCHAR(100) UNIQUE NOT NULL,
    phone CHAR(10),                    -- US phone: 2175551234
    birth_date DATE,
    registration_date DATETIME DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    is_active BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
    loyalty_points INT DEFAULT 0,
    account_balance DECIMAL(10,2) DEFAULT 0.00,
    membership_level ENUM('bronze', 'silver', 'gold', 'platinum')
);

docs.title: 3.4 The SELECT Statement
docs.text: The SELECT statement is used to retrieve data from databases.

docs.title: Basic Syntax
docs.text:
SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name;

docs.title: Selecting All Columns
docs.text:
SELECT * FROM employee;

Use SELECT * Carefully

While SELECT * is convenient, in production: - It's less efficient (retrieves unnecessary columns) - It's less clear what data you need - It can break code if table structure changes

Better: Explicitly list the columns you need

docs.title: Selecting Specific Columns
docs.text:
SELECT first_name, last_name, salary
FROM employee;

docs.title: Column Aliases
docs.text:
Use aliases to rename columns in the output:

SELECT
    first_name AS "First Name",
    last_name AS "Last Name",
    salary AS "Annual Salary"
FROM employee;

docs.title: Calculated Columns
docs.text:
SELECT
    first_name,
    last_name,
    salary,
    salary * 12 AS annual_salary,
    salary * 0.15 AS annual_tax
FROM employee;

docs.title: DISTINCT - Remove Duplicates
docs.text:
SELECT DISTINCT department_id
FROM employee;

Example: 

-- Find all unique cities where customers live
SELECT DISTINCT city
FROM customer;

docs.title: 3.5 Filtering with WHERE
docs.text: The WHERE clause filters rows based on conditions.

docs.title: Basic WHERE Syntax
docs.text:
SELECT column1, column2
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;

docs.title: Comparison Operators
docs.text:
Operator Meaning Example = Equal WHERE salary = 50000 <> or != Not equal WHERE department_id <> 5 > Greater than WHERE salary > 50000 < Less than WHERE age < 30 >= Greater than or equal WHERE hire_date >= '2020-01-01' <= Less than or equal WHERE price <= 100

Examples: 

-- Employees making more than $60,000
SELECT first_name, last_name, salary
FROM employee
WHERE salary > 60000;

-- Employees hired after January 1, 2020
SELECT first_name, last_name, hire_date
FROM employee
WHERE hire_date >= '2020-01-01';

docs.title: AND - Both conditions must be true
docs.text:
SELECT first_name, last_name, salary, department_id
FROM employee
WHERE salary > 50000 AND department_id = 3;

docs.title: OR - Either condition can be true
docs.text:
SELECT first_name, last_name, department_id
FROM employee
WHERE department_id = 1 OR department_id = 3;

docs.title: NOT - Negates a condition
docs.text:
SELECT first_name, last_name, department_id
FROM employee
WHERE NOT department_id = 5;

docs.title: Combining Logical Operators
docs.text:
-- Employees in dept 1 or 3, making more than $50k
SELECT first_name, last_name, salary, department_id
FROM employee
WHERE (department_id = 1 OR department_id = 3)
  AND salary > 50000;

Use Parentheses!

Always use parentheses to make the logic clear: 

-- Unclear (probably wrong):
WHERE dept = 1 OR dept = 2 AND salary > 50000

-- Clear (correct):
WHERE (dept = 1 OR dept = 2) AND salary > 50000

docs.title: Pattern Matching with LIKE
docs.text:
LIKE is used for pattern matching in strings:

  • % matches any sequence of characters
  • _ matches exactly one character

Examples: 

-- Customers whose last name starts with 'S'
SELECT first_name, last_name
FROM customer
WHERE last_name LIKE 'S%';

-- Customers whose email is from gmail
SELECT first_name, last_name, email
FROM customer
WHERE email LIKE '%@gmail.com';

-- Customers whose first name is 4 letters starting with 'J'
SELECT first_name, last_name
FROM customer
WHERE first_name LIKE 'J___';  -- J + 3 underscores

docs.title: Range Conditions with BETWEEN
docs.text:
-- Employees with salary between $40,000 and $60,000
SELECT first_name, last_name, salary
FROM employee
WHERE salary BETWEEN 40000 AND 60000;
-- Equivalent to: WHERE salary >= 40000 AND salary <= 60000

-- Orders placed in January 2024
SELECT order_id, order_date, total_amount
FROM orders
WHERE order_date BETWEEN '2024-01-01' AND '2024-01-31';

docs.title: Membership with IN
docs.text:
-- Employees in departments 1, 3, or 5
SELECT first_name, last_name, department_id
FROM employee
WHERE department_id IN (1, 3, 5);
-- Equivalent to: WHERE department_id = 1 OR department_id = 3 OR department_id = 5

-- Customers from specific cities
SELECT first_name, last_name, city
FROM customer
WHERE city IN ('Chicago', 'Champaign', 'Urbana');

docs.title: NULL Values
docs.text:
-- Employees with no email
SELECT first_name, last_name
FROM employee
WHERE email IS NULL;

-- Employees with an email
SELECT first_name, last_name, email
FROM employee
WHERE email IS NOT NULL;

NULL is Special

You cannot use = NULL or <> NULL. Always use IS NULL or IS NOT NULL.

-- WRONG:
WHERE email = NULL

-- CORRECT:
WHERE email IS NULL

docs.title: Ascending Order (Default)
docs.text:
SELECT first_name, last_name, salary
FROM employee
ORDER BY salary;
-- or explicitly: ORDER BY salary ASC

docs.title: Descending Order
docs.text:
SELECT first_name, last_name, salary
FROM employee
ORDER BY salary DESC;

docs.title: Multiple Sort Columns
docs.text:
-- Sort by department, then by salary within department
SELECT first_name, last_name, department_id, salary
FROM employee
ORDER BY department_id ASC, salary DESC;

docs.title: Sorting by Column Position
docs.text:
-- Sort by the 3rd column (salary), then 1st column (first_name)
SELECT first_name, last_name, salary
FROM employee
ORDER BY 3 DESC, 1 ASC;

Column Position Sorting

While sorting by column position works, it's better to use column names for clarity: 

-- Less clear:
ORDER BY 3 DESC, 1 ASC

-- More clear:
ORDER BY salary DESC, first_name ASC

docs.title: MySQL/PostgreSQL - LIMIT
docs.text:
-- Get the top 10 highest-paid employees
SELECT first_name, last_name, salary
FROM employee
ORDER BY salary DESC
LIMIT 10;

-- Get rows 11-20 (pagination)
SELECT first_name, last_name, salary
FROM employee
ORDER BY salary DESC
LIMIT 10 OFFSET 10;

docs.title: SQL Server / MS Access - TOP
docs.text:
-- SQL Server syntax (different from MySQL!)
SELECT TOP 10 first_name, last_name, salary
FROM employee
ORDER BY salary DESC;

docs.title: 3.8 Aggregate Functions
docs.text: Aggregate functions perform calculations on sets of rows.

docs.title: Common Aggregate Functions
docs.text: Function Purpose Example COUNT() Count rows COUNT(*), COUNT(email) SUM() Sum values SUM(salary) AVG() Average value AVG(salary) MIN() Minimum value MIN(salary) MAX() Maximum value MAX(salary)

docs.title: COUNT - Counting Rows
docs.text:
-- Count all employees
SELECT COUNT(*) AS employee_count
FROM employee;

-- Count employees with email addresses
SELECT COUNT(email) AS employees_with_email
FROM employee;

-- Count unique departments
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT department_id) AS department_count
FROM employee;

COUNT(*) vs COUNT(column)

  • COUNT(*) counts all rows
  • COUNT(column) counts rows where column IS NOT NULL
  • COUNT(DISTINCT column) counts unique non-NULL values

docs.title: SUM - Total
docs.text:
-- Total salary expense
SELECT SUM(salary) AS total_salary_expense
FROM employee;

-- Total sales
SELECT SUM(amount) AS total_sales
FROM orders
WHERE order_date >= '2024-01-01';

docs.title: AVG - Average
docs.text:
-- Average salary
SELECT AVG(salary) AS average_salary
FROM employee;

-- Average order value
SELECT AVG(total_amount) AS average_order_value
FROM orders;

docs.title: MIN and MAX
docs.text:
-- Salary range
SELECT
    MIN(salary) AS lowest_salary,
    MAX(salary) AS highest_salary,
    MAX(salary) - MIN(salary) AS salary_range
FROM employee;

-- Earliest and latest hire dates
SELECT
    MIN(hire_date) AS first_hire,
    MAX(hire_date) AS most_recent_hire
FROM employee;

docs.title: Combining Aggregate Functions
docs.text:
SELECT
    COUNT(*) AS total_employees,
    AVG(salary) AS avg_salary,
    MIN(salary) AS min_salary,
    MAX(salary) AS max_salary,
    SUM(salary) AS total_payroll
FROM employee;

docs.title: Marketing: Customer Analysis
docs.text:
-- Find all customers who joined in the last year
SELECT customer_id, first_name, last_name, registration_date
FROM customer
WHERE registration_date >= DATE_SUB(CURRENT_DATE, INTERVAL 1 YEAR)
ORDER BY registration_date DESC;

-- Find customers from Illinois
SELECT first_name, last_name, email, city
FROM customer
WHERE state = 'IL'
ORDER BY city, last_name;

docs.title: Finance: Transaction Analysis
docs.text:
-- Find all high-value transactions
SELECT transaction_id, customer_id, amount, transaction_date
FROM transactions
WHERE amount > 1000
ORDER BY amount DESC
LIMIT 20;

-- Summary statistics
SELECT
    COUNT(*) AS total_transactions,
    SUM(amount) AS total_revenue,
    AVG(amount) AS avg_transaction_value,
    MAX(amount) AS largest_transaction
FROM transactions
WHERE transaction_date >= '2024-01-01';

docs.title: HR: Employee Analysis
docs.text:
-- Find recently hired employees
SELECT first_name, last_name, hire_date, department_id
FROM employee
WHERE hire_date >= '2024-01-01'
ORDER BY hire_date DESC;

-- Salary statistics by department
SELECT
    department_id,
    COUNT(*) AS employee_count,
    AVG(salary) AS avg_salary,
    MIN(salary) AS min_salary,
    MAX(salary) AS max_salary
FROM employee
GROUP BY department_id;

docs.title: Key Takeaways
docs.text:
1. SQL is the universal language for working with relational databases
  2. Choose appropriate data types to ensure data integrity and performance
  3. SELECT retrieves data - be specific about which columns you need
  4. WHERE filters rows - use comparison and logical operators effectively
  5. ORDER BY sorts results - critical for meaningful output
  6. Aggregate functions summarize data - COUNT, SUM, AVG, MIN, MAX
  7. Practice is essential - the more queries you write, the more comfortable you'll become

docs.title: Review Questions
docs.text:
1. What's the difference between CHAR and VARCHAR data types?
  2. Write a query to find all products priced between $10 and $50, sorted by price.
  3. Explain the difference between COUNT(*) and COUNT(column_name).
  4. Why should you avoid using SELECT * in production code?
  5. What's wrong with this query: WHERE email = NULL?

docs.title: Practical Exercise
docs.text:
Given this PRODUCT table: 

PRODUCT
+------------+-----------------+-------+----------+-----------+
| Product_ID | Product_Name    | Price | Category | Stock_Qty |
+------------+-----------------+-------+----------+-----------+
| P001       | Laptop          | 999   | Tech     | 15        |
| P002       | Mouse           | 25    | Tech     | 150       |
| P003       | Desk Chair      | 250   | Furniture| 30        |
| P004       | Monitor         | 350   | Tech     | 45        |
| P005       | Standing Desk   | 600   | Furniture| 12        |
+------------+-----------------+-------+----------+-----------+

Write SQL queries for:

  1. Find all Tech products
  2. Find products priced over $200
  3. Find the average price of all products
  4. Find products with less than 20 items in stock
  5. Find all products with "Desk" in the name
  6. Calculate the total value of inventory (Price × Stock_Qty for all products)

docs.title: SQL - SQL Fundamentals

docs.title: Course Identifier
docs.text: Course Code: BADM 554 Institution: University of Illinois Instructor: Vishal Sachdev Target Concepts: 231

docs.title: Course Overview
docs.text: Databases play a critical role in today's business environment. Almost all modern organizations use database technologies to store and manage data in every functional area including operations, finance, accounting, and marketing. This course will equip you with one of the most marketable skills to help businesses better manage their data and discover new opportunities.

docs.title: Target Audience
docs.text:
This course is designed for:

  • Graduate business students seeking practical database skills
  • Business analysts and managers who need to work with data
  • Students with basic computer literacy but no prior database experience
  • Professionals transitioning into data-driven business roles

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Basic computer skills (file management, web browsing)
  • Familiarity with spreadsheet applications (Excel, Google Sheets)
  • Basic understanding of business concepts
  • No prior programming experience required

docs.title: 1. Database Fundamentals (Weeks 1-2)
docs.text:
• Data vs. Information
  • Database concepts and terminology
  • Database Management Systems (DBMS)
  • Database users and roles
  • Database system components
  • Data models overview

docs.title: 2. Relational Model & Tables (Weeks 2-3)
docs.text:
• Relational model concepts
  • Tables, rows, and columns
  • Keys (primary, foreign, composite)
  • Relationships (one-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-many)
  • Relational algebra operations
  • Set operations

docs.title: 3. SQL Fundamentals (Weeks 3-5)
docs.text:
• SQL history and standards
  • Data Definition Language (DDL)
  • Data Manipulation Language (DML)
  • SELECT statements
  • WHERE clauses and filtering
  • Sorting and ordering
  • Aggregate functions (COUNT, SUM, AVG, MIN, MAX)
  • GROUP BY and HAVING
  • Basic joins (INNER, LEFT, RIGHT)

docs.title: 4. Advanced SQL (Weeks 5-7)
docs.text:
• Complex joins and self-joins
  • Subqueries (scalar, table, correlated)
  • Common Table Expressions (CTEs)
  • Window functions
  • CASE statements
  • String functions and pattern matching
  • Date/time functions
  • NULL handling

docs.title: 5. JSON Data & APIs (Week 7-8)
docs.text:
• JSON structure and syntax
  • JSON data types
  • Querying JSON in databases
  • JSON functions in SQL
  • RESTful APIs basics
  • API authentication
  • Data extraction from APIs
  • Working with nested JSON

docs.title: 6. Database Design & Modeling (Weeks 8-10)
docs.text:
• Entity-Relationship (ER) modeling
  • ER diagrams and notation
  • Entities, attributes, and relationships
  • Cardinality and participation
  • Weak entities
  • Enhanced ER (EER) features
  • Translating ER to relational schema
  • MySQL Workbench for modeling

docs.title: 7. Normalization (Week 10-11)
docs.text:
• Data redundancy problems
  • Update, insertion, and deletion anomalies
  • Functional dependencies
  • First Normal Form (1NF)
  • Second Normal Form (2NF)
  • Third Normal Form (3NF)
  • Boyce-Codd Normal Form (BCNF)
  • Denormalization trade-offs

docs.title: 8. Data Warehousing & ETL (Weeks 11-12)
docs.text:
• OLTP vs. OLAP
  • Data warehouse architecture
  • Star schema
  • Snowflake schema
  • Fact tables and dimension tables
  • ETL process overview
  • ETL tools (Knime)
  • Data quality and cleansing
  • Data transformation techniques

docs.title: 9. NoSQL Databases (Weeks 13-14)
docs.text:
• NoSQL overview and motivation
  • CAP theorem
  • Document databases (MongoDB)
  • Key-value stores
  • Column-family stores
  • Graph databases
  • MongoDB operations (CRUD)
  • MongoDB query language
  • When to use NoSQL vs. SQL

docs.title: 10. Development Environment & Tools
docs.text:
• MySQL installation and configuration
  • PostgreSQL setup
  • Jupyter Notebooks with Python
  • Google Colab environment
  • MySQL Workbench
  • Knime workflow tool
  • MongoDB Compass
  • SQL clients and IDEs

docs.title: 11. Python for Database Operations
docs.text:
• Database connectivity (libraries)
  • Executing SQL from Python
  • Parameterized queries
  • Transaction management
  • Error handling
  • Data visualization with database data
  • Pandas integration with databases

docs.title: 12. Business Applications
docs.text:
• Marketing analytics (customer segmentation)
  • Supply chain management (vendor analysis)
  • Financial analysis (macroeconomic research)
  • Accounting applications (fraud detection)
  • Business intelligence dashboards
  • Real-world case studies

docs.title: Topics Explicitly Excluded
docs.text:
• Advanced database administration (backup/recovery, replication)
  • Database security and encryption
  • Query optimization and indexing strategies
  • Distributed database systems
  • Real-time streaming databases
  • Blockchain and distributed ledger technologies
  • Advanced machine learning integration
  • Database performance tuning
  • Cloud database migration strategies
  • Database as a Service (DBaaS) platforms in depth

docs.title: Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

  1. Understand and articulate the data needs of a company (requirement analysis)
  2. Conceptually model the relationship of data using ER diagrams (data modeling)
  3. Query databases using SQL to meet business requirements (structured and non-relational)
  4. Design normalized databases that avoid data anomalies
  5. Extract, Transform, and Load (ETL) data from/to multiple sources
  6. Work with JSON data and integrate API data into databases
  7. Understand infrastructure needs to handle Big Data and build BI workflows
  8. Choose appropriate database technologies for different business scenarios
  9. Use Python to interact with databases programmatically
  10. Apply database skills to solve real-world business problems in marketing, finance, operations, and accounting

docs.title: Bloom's Taxonomy Alignment
docs.text:
• Remember (15%): Database terminology, SQL syntax, normalization rules
  • Understand (25%): Database concepts, relational model, ER diagrams, data warehousing principles
  • Apply (35%): Writing SQL queries, creating ER diagrams, normalizing databases, ETL workflows
  • Analyze (15%): Evaluating database designs, identifying data anomalies, choosing appropriate technologies
  • Evaluate (5%): Assessing database performance, comparing SQL vs NoSQL
  • Create (5%): Designing complete database solutions for business problems

docs.title: Assessment Methods
docs.text:
• Weekly SQL assignments
  • Database design projects
  • ETL workflow implementation
  • Final capstone project integrating multiple concepts
  • Quizzes on foundational concepts

docs.title: Tools and Technologies
docs.text:
• MySQL (version 8.0+)
  • PostgreSQL (version 13+)
  • MongoDB (version 5.0+)
  • Python (version 3.8+) with libraries: pymysql, psycopg2, pymongo, pandas
  • Jupyter Notebooks via Google Colab
  • MySQL Workbench (for ER modeling)
  • Knime Analytics Platform (for ETL)
  • MongoDB Compass (for NoSQL exploration)

docs.title: Course Philosophy
docs.text:
This course emphasizes practical, hands-on learning with real business scenarios. Every concept is reinforced with:

  • Business context and motivation
  • Interactive examples
  • Hands-on labs
  • Real-world datasets
  • Industry-relevant tools

The goal is for students to leave the course with immediately applicable skills that can be used in their careers.
